post.body: Glad that psake is bringing a smile to your face. If you have any suggestions for improvement, please let me know.
Why do you have to qualify that statement with "in a C# project"? :) Sorry, VBers. That was just plain mean on my part...
@haacked Yes, your assumption is correct. R#r builds its own AST and caches it in _ReSharper.<SlnName> or TEMP.
I haven't found the additional R#r files to be a problem. R#r can store caches in TEMP if desired. R#r Options... General...
If you're running any ReSharper add-ins, I would try disabling them as I've found some can cause stability issues.
Welcome to the Twitterverse. Now I can publicly proclaim my love for you. :)
I'll submit a feature request for xunit to support per-assembly setup/teardown. Thanks.
When I read the xunit docs, it sounded like you got one T per typeof(T) rather than per-class that used T.
You can achieve much the same result as per-assembly setup/teardown if IUseFixture<T> creates one T per typeof(T). Thoughts?
Personally I thought Keaton's Batman was superb as was Nicholson's Joker. But maybe that's just nostalgia.
West's Batman voice was campy and fit the show. Bale's Batman voice was cheesier than a well-aged cheddar.
I was going to do what I do every night - try to take over the world! But it's too frigging cold out. So I chose xunit instead.
I had a simple TC 3.2 install (relatively fresh) that I upgraded to TC 4.0. All 4 builds came over.
I hadn't realized. Like the moon, Liskov is a harsh mistress... (Geek points if you can name the author to which I'm alluding.)
Thanks for the heads-up. The only TC plug-in that I need right now is Gallio, which is compatible with 4.0.
TeamCity 4.0 contains lots of new features (http://tinyurl.com/6g3e2u) and the upgrade is fast and simple. No reason not to.
and I had a good mindmeld over writing a MEF article together. MEF, like ASP.NET MVC, are very promising techs coming from Redmond.
Can't believe in one week I'll be flying solo at home with two young kids... :)
I completely agree. ASP.NET MVC continues to evolve in positive ways that I would personally call Beta2, not RC.
Awesome! I'll have to run a svn update on Sharp Architecture and check it out. Thanks!
I've been looking at Sharp Arch. Overall I like it, though I don't like that 3rd party dependencies are all dumped into sln items.
Welcome back to the Twitterverse.
Which part? Strongly-typed views or C#/VB syntax in Inherits="ViewPage<T>"?
Depends. If you're experiencing pain with CC.NET, then try porting a project or two over to TeamCity. Personally I prefer TC now.
Decided that I needed to update some demos for tomorrow's presentation more than I needed to go to the DevTeach attendee party... :^(
Heading off to the DevTeach attendee party...
Sitting in Greg Young's TDD in a DbC World...
Heading out to the DevTeach speakers dinner...
Off to grab a coffee and then onto the DevTeach keynote... Good luck, @tedneward.
Off to Ye Olde Orchard to meet up with @dbelcham, @gotwoods, @ayende, and whomever else happens to be around...
Je suis a Montreal. Time to see how much high school French I've forgotten. It's rusty by less than two decades. Bon chance a moi!
Sitting in YYC waiting for my flight to DevTeach Montreal. Should be a blast!
What exactly is TripIt trying to tell me? "Closeness Alerts @dbelcham will be close to you on this trip." I am frightened. Very frightened.
In April Blizzard joked it was releasing WoW for the Atari 2600. http://tinyurl.com/2gzrdj Someone actually did. http://tinyurl.com/69u8hl
Simplifying application wire-up using Windsor. The fluent config is very nice. Gradually migrating to convention-based config. Even nicer.
You know you've been using ReSharper too much when you find yourself automatically pressing ALT-ENTER for errors in Office documents...
Personally I still find R#r more compelling for other reasons, namely code browsing and analysis. I'll have to blog about it...
RE:CodeRush vs. R#r for TDD. I compared them a few years ago and at the time R#r was far better. Sounds like CR has improved. Good for them!
Been sick since Sunday and had to cancel my talk at the Alberta Architect Forum on Thursday as I doubt my voice will return in time. :^(
Catching up at home after DevTeach...
Another successful DevTeach. Thanks, Montreal, it's been fun. Now I'm headed to the airport after a blissful 2 hours of sleep...
OH: @ayende is a great big puppy when he is a drunk.
I'm acting as neutral territory between Israel and the 'Peg...
Off to an Italian restaurant with a bunch of my fellow DevTeach speakers...
Agile Q&A with James Kovacs and Friends this afternoon. Just have to make sure my Friends show up. I'll try to live up to Laribee's example.
Feeling very pleased with how my IoC and PI sessions turned out... Highest review scores I've ever received! :)
Getting ready to fly to Toronto for my grandfather's funeral... :^(
Sitting in YYC wondering if my flight will leave on time or at all. Lots of delays and cancellations due to weather.
Gotta love AirCanada. 20 minutes past boarding time, plane just pulled up to the gate, and they're reporting "on time". Somehow I think not.
AirCanada has an extremely generous notion of "on time". Should have flown WestJet...
Why do Toronto drivers insist on cutting into funeral processions? Talk about disrespect!
Feeling very metrosexual after watching two inflight movies - The Dark Knight and Mama Mia! Both were alright, but not stellar.
I wanted to use xunit's IUseFixture<T> with WatiN and Cassini to perform acceptance testing. Any xunit gurus know if this is possible?
xunit's IUseFixture<T> creates a new T per test class/fixture. So it's not usable as per-assembly setup/teardown for starting a webserver.
Taking xunit for a spin... IUseFixture<T> for per-fixture setup/teardown is interesting. Time to see if it works per-assembly too...
Spent the afternoon spiking replacement of repo layer with Fluent NHib. Very nice.
Liskov is king. Cross him and you're in for a world of pain. Fixing LSP issues now, which is dramatically simplifying IoC config.
MS Fargo Campus pokes fun at MS Redmond Campus for their weather problems. http://blogs.msdn.com/oldnewthing/archive/2008/12/22/9244583.aspx
Hi-ho, hi-ho, a-refactoring we will go...
Looks like VS2010 is getting a heap of ReSharper-like features for navigation and code creation. http://tinyurl.com/ayc64v
My Virtual Server at GoDaddy is running low on memory. The only way to increase from 512 to 768MB RAM is to reprovision it. Fail!!!
TIP: When refactoring, apply multiple automated refactoring to get from A-B-C-D instead of breaking your code by going directly from A to D.
ASP.NET MVC Team - Whatever happened to going from Beta to RC with only bug fixes? If you are adding features, you're not RC IMHO.
ASP.NET MVC missed the boat on scaffolding though. It shouldn't be a wizard IMHO. Show me a default view so that I can rapidly prototype.
